{{disambig-two|the father of [[Ælfwine]]|seventh [[King of Rohan]]|[[Déor]]}} {{anglosaxon infobox | name=Déor | image= | people=[[wikipedia:Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] | caption= | pronun= | othernames= | titles= | position=[[Minstrels|Minstrel]] | location=[[Lionesse]]
[[Kortirion#Other versions of the legendarium|Kortirion]] | affiliation= | language=[[Old English]] | birth= | birthlocation= | rule= | death= | deathlocation= | age= | notablefor= | house= | parentage= | siblings= | spouse=[[Éadgifu]] | children=[[Ælfwine]] | gender=Male | height= | hair= | eyes= | clothing= | weapons= | steed= }} '''Déor''' was an [[wikipedia:English people|English]] [[Minstrels|minstrel]], and the father of [[Ælfwine]], according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] in the text called ''[[Ælfwine of England]]'' from ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''. == History == Déor came from somewhere in the south of [[Luthany|Lúthien]], though he also spent some time in [[Lionesse]] where he met his wife, whom he called [[Éadgifu]]. Later, he moved to the city of [[Kortirion#Other versions of the legendarium|Kortirion]],Kortirion was the [[Qenya|Elvish]] name of the town of [[wikipedia:Warwick|Warwick]].{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''30''', p. 310 ruled by the [[Prince of Gwar]] called [[Óswine (prince of Gwar)|Óswine]], for he wished to be close to the [[Elves]], who still lived around the city since Óswine was friendly to them. There, Éadgifu gave birth to their son Ælfwine, who inherited her mother's unquenchable longing for the sea. However, while Ælfwine was still a boy, a fierce people called the [[Forodwaith (The Book of Lost Tales)|Forodwaith]] (i.e. [[wikipedia:Vikings|Vikings]]) attacked Kortirion and laid siege to it, during which Déor died leading a "desperate sally" before the walls,{{LT2|VIb}}, p. 313-4 slain by [[Orm]] the sea-captain of the Forodwaith.{{LT2|VIb}}, p. 318 == Etymology == The name ''Déor'' is in [[Old English]], meaning "brave, bold".{{HM|RC}}, p. 643 In one occurrence, the character was called ''Heorrenda'' before being changed back to ''Déor''.{{LT2|VIb}}, ''Changes made to names, and differences in names, in the texts of Ælfwine of England'', p. 334 == Genealogy == {{familytree/start}} {{familytree | DEO |y| EAD |DEO='''DÉOR'''|EAD=[[Éadgifu]]|}} {{familytree | | | |!| | | |}} {{familytree | | | ÆLF | | |ÆLF=[[Ælfwine]]|}} {{familytree/end}} == Inspiration == The character of Déor was probably inspired by the Old English poem ''[[Déor (poem)|Déor]]'', which also features a minstrel as the eponymous main character. However, according to [[Christopher Tolkien]], the only link between the two characters is their name.{{LT2|VIb}}, p. 323 == See also == *[[Éadwine]], the father of Ælfwine in the later [[legendarium]] *[[Eoh]], the father of [[Eriol]] in the earlier legendarium {{references|notes}} {{title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Deor (father of Ælfwine)}} [[Category:Anglo-Saxons]] [[Category:Characters in The Book of Lost Tales]] [[Category:Minstrels]] [[Category:Old English names]]
